question.text: This product ___ our most popular item.

answer.explanation: (D) “Always” comes between the auxiliary and be (if be occurs in the sentence). Choices (A), (B), and (C) do not place “always” between the auxiliary and “be”.

question.text: ___Mr. Lee works very hard and always meets his deadlines, he still hasn’t been given a promotion.

answer.explanation: (D) “Although” implies a contrast between the two clauses; one would expect hardworldng Mr. Lee to get a promotion, but he hasn’t gotten one. Choice (A) indicates a cause-and-effect relationship. Choice (B) could be used with “though” but cannot stand alone in this sentence. Choice (C) needs to be followed by a gerund, not a clause.

question.text: The goal of our publication is to provide ___ to students who want to study overseas.
Everyone is expected to arrive at the meeting___.

answer.explanation: (C) This is an adverb of manner used to describe the verb “arrive”. Choice (A) is a noun. Choice (B) is a verb and belongs to a different word family. Choice (D) is an adjective.

question.text: The head of operations ___ to the management convention.

answer.explanation: (D) “Head of operations” requires a singular verb. Choice (A) is a gerund. Choice (B) is plural. Choice (C) is the simple form.

question.text: The manager got his staff ___ last weekend.

answer.explanation: (A) The causative “got” requires a following infinitive. Choice (B) is the past progressive. Choice (C) is an adjective. Choice (D) is the simple past.

question.text: ___ budget constraints, all full-time employees will receive a 3 percent salary increase.

answer.explanation:
"When" and "even if" do not go with a noun.
The two clauses have different meanings so we choose "despite".

question.text: Insadong Images proudly ___ Machiko Nakamura as its new senior graphics designer.
He___an employee of this company ever since he first started working.

answer.explanation: (C) This is a present perfect verb used to describe an action that started in the past and continues into the present. Choice (A) is simple present tense. Choice (B) is past tense. Choice (D) is future tense.
(B) The blank requires an adjective; “available” is the only one given. Choices (A) and (D) are verbs. Choice (C) is a noun.
